subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Call of Cthul hu: Typo Report: ¶6, ¶7; more nam e-dot confusion
msgSnippet: ...  Indeed! I wonder if I ve missed that until now or simply forgotten it; IME speakers who have [u:]/[i:] for stressed GOOSE and FLEECE actually
messageBody:
2013-05-19 16:05, John Cowan skrev:
> BPJ scripsit:
>
>> The first edition of LPD (1990) says:
>> *to* strong form [tu:], weak forms [tu], [t@]
>> *too* [tu:] -- this word has no weak form.
>> *two* [tu:] (= _too_).
>> No indication of differing GenAm/RP pronunciations though!
>
> There is no difference in this word, with the general caveat that
> length-marks don't represent length variations in American English,
> which obeys a variant of the Scottish Vowel Length Rule.
>
>> So the problem is that QS has no way of unambiguously spelling
>> the 'intermediate' [u], but it seems sensible to make a
>> distinction and spell out _to_ as <tU>.
>
> In LPD, [u] is an abbreviation meaning "either [u:] or [U] depending on
> the speaker", as [i] means "either [i:] or [I]". Almost certainly Read
> had [U].

<slaps head> Indeed! I wonder if I've missed that until now or
simply forgotten it; IME speakers who have [u:]/[i:] for
stressed GOOSE and FLEECE actually have [u]/[i] for those when
unstressed, so I've at least grown accustomed to take those
transcriptions at face value. That said my L1 certainly doesn't
poise me to perceive length distinctions in fully unstressed
vowels!

>
> As ODO explains, it is [u] before vowels and [@] before consonants.
>

LPD advises EFL learners to use that distribution, but warns that
native speakers sometimes use [t@] before vowels, which doesn't
surprise me a bit since any English vowel may become [@] when
fully unstressed in allegro speech.

/bpj
